content:
‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I really like this Clash a bit difficult but if you read the whole description, it gets easier to understand. It can also be a great puzzle idea with some modifications !

‚ùå Rejected the contribution.
Comment: It's too difficult.
It should be a 'puzzle'.

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: ELLE EST COOL

1) I'd like to see this as an easy puzzle, but it is probably solvable (barely) as a clash given the full 15 minutes.
2) Your description is very good though there is a lot to absorb to solve this problem.
3) The test cases seem very good.
4) This is NOT reversible.  Please remove.  I cannot approve this with that there. I'd even love to see Shortest go.  There is no time margin to add additional work.
5) Perhaps "si" should be "ti"?  This is the common phrasing for Tonic Solfa notation (at least in English and the movie "Sound of Music").  See: 
https://violinspiration.com/do-re-mi-fa-so-la-ti-do/

Notes system "do, re ..., si" is not the most popular.
Good puzzle but I don't think its place is in the "clash". Better in easy solo puzzle.

An excellent puzzle, but perhaps better suited for a Puzzle than a time-restricted Clash.

I don't think it's suitable for Reverse, as not everyone is familiar with the do-re-me system, or musical clefs, and it takes too long to deduce it from nothing. Perhaps if Test 1 was a simple treble scale (like Test 2 is for baritone), it would be possible to figure out in time.

Treble clef "la" is never used.

For constraints section,
I think you may have at least one constraint that all 10 input lines will have a maximum length of 26.

( I find it hard to interpret 0s in input right away. I will try to test the problem in IDE before I comment more on it. I will update this one then. )

Goal section
* Are "Cle de Fa" and "Cle de sol" French? Based on Wikipedia:
   ‚Ä¢ Please replace "Cle de Fa" with "treble clef (ùÑû)".
   ‚Ä¢ Please replace "Cle de sol" with "baritone clef (ùÑ¢)".
   Please be reminded that the terms should be defined (and best with the symbols!), as not everybody knows them. I'm not even sure whether my understanding is correct or not...

* Please also add to the statement an explanation of how the other notes should be read if I see a ùÑû or a ùÑ¢.

Input section / Stub generator
* If there are always 10 lines in each case, you may simplify the inputs and stub generator to remove that from input.

Constraints section
* If the last comment is adopted, you may remove this constraint as well. Otherwise, at least simplify it as [[N]] = 10.

Thanks.
Thank you very much, I have made the suggested changes.
Thank you, I have updated the Input section to precise that each line is always composed of 26 chars
Thank you, I have updated the Test 1 with a simple treble scale, which includes treble clef "la", so it is suitable for reverse.
Thank you, it is not necessary to know the system to solve this Clash. I will re submit it as an easy puzzle if it is not accepted as a Clash.
Thank you, I have implemented all your points. (Except the change to the easy puzzle, I can't transform my clash into an easy puzzle)

Thank you.

* Please change "an so on" to "and so on" (twice).

* Please also mention that:
   ‚Ä¢ The notes wrap around (we go back to <<do>> after <<si>>).
   ‚Ä¢ We go up a note when we move from a space/line to the line/space immediately above.
   ‚Ä¢ We go down a note when we move from a space/line to the line/space immediately below.

Thanks again :)
